description: From French précaution, Latin praecautio, from praecavere, praecautum (“to guard against beforehand”); prae (“before”) + cavere (“be on one's guard”). See pre-, and caution.

entries.meaning: Previous caution or care; caution previously employed to prevent misfortune or to secure good
examples: his life was saved by precaution

entries.meaning: A measure taken beforehand to ward off evil or secure good or success; a precautionary act.
examples: to take precautions against risks of accident

verbs.description: precaution (third-person singular simple present precautions, present participle precautioning, simple past and past participle precautioned)
